posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content:
Okay, in a better place.  Weapon crafting on WoG has become rather dynamic and there are a lot of options, and more on the way from I've heard.

For socketing in general, there's a few rules you want to abide by:  place one gem of each type you want to socket into the weapon.  Do not stack gems of the same type on top of each other until you fill all the slots first.  You can do that if you want, but you squander precious gem slots doing so (Moradin knows I lost quite a few until I figured it out).

Here's an example.  You have Longbow with 3 gems slots.  Longbows cannot be enhanced but they can be given attack bonuses, Mighty properties, and other general properties.  Say you have a +2 Attack Gem, a +1 Forceful Gem (mighty prop), and a +1 Deft Gem.  But you also have 2 other Forceful gems and a +1 Attack gem.  So, how to begin?  Socket one gem type of the properties you desire.  Socket the +2 Attack gem, then socket one of your forcefuls, and then your Deft gem.  You have now taken up all 3 socket slots with three different properties.  Once you do this, then you can begin to stack.  You can continue to stack Attack bonus gems on top of the current one, as well as the Forceful and Deft (dexterity).  

Ability bonus gems like Deft Gem cap out at +4.  I'm not sure where Forceful caps out but it's probably in the +4-+6 region.  Same goes for Attack gems.  Regeneration won't stack, so you can only have +1 regen on any one item.  I haven't found the ceiling for skill point gems, but it's probably in the neighborhood of an Epic Skill Focus increase.  Obviously the more slots you have, the more properties you can add.  

Sometimes you have to wait for the right gems to come along.  It's totally random but sometimes you get lucky.  For instance, the gems I find that other players sell the most are Forceful gems, Airy, Arcanic Armor, and Attack Bonus gems (the actual name eludes me right now).

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content: You can't put elemental damage on ranged weapons because they don't actually do damage.  It's the arrow (or bolt and bullet) that deals the damage.  You might be able to put elemental resistance on your bow but I haven't actually tested this yet.
